Note.definition: a written promise to pay a debt ;specif

1 a.definition: a written promise to pay a debtin this entry

bank note.definition: a promissory note issued by a bank payable to bearer on demand but without interest and circulating as money

cog·no·vit note.definition: [kÄ g-nō-vit-, kōg-]a note in which the maker acknowledges the debt and authorizes the entry of judgment against him or her without notice or a hearinga note containing a confession of judgment

collateral note.definition: a note secured esp. by a collateral mortgage and pledged to secure an obligation of which a hand note usually serves as evidence

demand note.definition: a note payable on demand comparein this entry

floating rate note.definition: a negotiable note that yields an indexed and periodically adjusted variable rate of interest called also

hand note.definition: a note for an obligation secured by a collateral note

non-recourse note.definition: a note whose satisfaction upon default may be obtained only out of the collateral securing it

promissory note.definition: a note containing an unconditional promise to pay on demand or at a fixed or determined future time a particular sum of money to or to the order of a specified person or to the bearer

recourse note.definition: a note whose satisfaction upon default may be obtained from the debtor's assets other than and in addition to the collateral securing it

re·new·al note.definition: a note that continues an obligation due under a previous note

tax an·tic·i·pa·tion note.definition: a note issued by a state or municipality on pending tax revenue to fund immediate governmental expenditures

time note.definition: a note payable at a specified time in the future comparein this entry

Treasury note.definition: a negotiable note issued by the U.S. government with a maturity date of one to ten years from the date of issue called alsocompareatat

2.definition: to make a notarial memorandum of nonpayment of (a negotiable instrument) on presentation

1.definition: to recognize the existence or presence of [probable jurisdiction]
